acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Although there are no test results available for its R isomers, rat dermal LD50 for epichlorohydrin (CAS No. 106-89-8) is 754 mg/kg (EHC 33 (1984)). Therefore, the substance was classified into Category 3.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: No data available. As relevant notes, epichlorohydrin (CAS No. 106-89-8) is a liquid by GHS definition.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Although there are no test results available for its R isomers, rat LC50 for epichlorohydrin (CAS No. 106-89-8) by inhalation is 0.95 mg/L (4-hour exposure) or 250 ppm (Initial Environmental Risk Assessment of Chemicals (Ministry of the Environment), vol. 1, 2002). Therefore, the substance was classified into Category 2.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Although there are no test results available for its R isomers, rat oral LD50 for epichlorohydrin (CAS No. 106-89-8) is 90 mg/kg (Initial Environmental Risk Assessment of Chemicals (Ministry of the Environment), vol. 1, 2002). Therefore, the substance was classified into Category 3.

carcinogenicity.rationale: It is rated as "Carc. Cat. 2" by the EU; however, since we cannot verify the data that support the rating, we classified the substance into the "Classification not possible" category. As relevant notes, epichlorohydrin (CAS No. 106-89-8) is rated as "R" by the NTP and "Group 2A by the IARC (equivalent to GHS Category 1B) (US-NTP (2005), IARC 71 (1999)).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data. (The EU's Risk Phrase for this substance is R34: causes burns.)

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

flammable_liquids.rationale: 1) Since its flash point reported by ICSC is 33degC (closed cup), the substance was classified into Category 3 (RS isomers). 2) UN 2023, Class 3 (Subsidiary Risk) (RS isomers).

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Since chromosomal aberrations and sister chromatid exchanges were observed in mouse bone marrow (RTECS accessed in November 2007), the substance was classified into Category 2. As additional background information, in vitro reverse mutation tests also gave positive results (RTECS accessed in November 2007).

organic_peroxides.rationale: Organic compounds containing no bivalent -O-O- structure

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: The substance contains chlorine and oxygen (but not fluorine), which are chemically bonded only to carbon or hydrogen.

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Since its autoignition point is reported to be 385degC (Chemical Risk Information Platform (CHRIP)), it does not ignite at room temperature (RS isomers).

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Although there are no test results available for this substance, oral administration of epichlorohydrin (CAS No. 106-89-8) to rats showed effects on fertility of male rats such as sterility and decreased numbers of fertilized eggs and implantation (Hazard Assessment Report (CERI, NITE) 2004) while effects on parental animals were not clear. Based on this report, this substance was classified into Category 2.

respiratory_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause allergy or asthma symptoms or breathing difficulties if inhaled
respiratory_sensitizer.rationale: Although there are no test results available for its R isomers, epichlorohydrin (CAS No. 106-89-8) is documented to cause chronic asthmatic bronchitis according to the human health effect data (Initial Environmental Risk Assessment of Chemicals (Ministry of the Environment), vol. 1, 2002), and it is considered to be a respiratory sensitizer. Consequently, this substance was classified into Category 1.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: UN 2023, Division 6.1, packing group II (RS isomers)

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Although there are no test results available for its R isomers, epichlorohydrin (CAS No. 106-89-8) was found to be corrosive in eye irritation test using rabbits (Hazard Assessment Report (CERI, NITE) 2004). In addition, epichlorohydrin has been found to be skin corrosive. Therefore, the substance was classified into Category 1.

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Although there are no test results available for its R isomers, epichlorohydrin (CAS No. 106-89-8) was found to be corrosive in skin irritation test using rabbits (Hazard Assessment Report (CERI, NITE) 2004). Therefore, the substance was classified into Category 1.

skin_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
skin_sensitizer.rationale: Although there are no test results available for its R isomers, epichlorohydrin (CAS No. 106-89-8) was found to be a skin sensitizer in guinea pigs (Hazard Assessment Report (CERI, NITE) 2004; ACGIH (2001); Initial Environmental Risk Assessment of Chemicals (Ministry of the Environment), vol. 1, 2002; EHC 33 (1984)). Consequently, this substance was classified into Category 1.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.classification: Category 1 (digestive system, respiratory system, kidney, liver)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (digestive system, respiratory system, kidney, liver)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Although there are no test results available for this substance, oral administration of epichlorohydrin (CAS No. 106-89-8) in animal tests resulted in inflammation and degeneration of the digestive system, hyperplasia of mucosa, and degeneration of renal tubules. In inhalation exposure tests, inflammation and degeneration of the respiratory system, pulmonary congestion and edema, hepatic congestion and necrosis, and atrophy of renal tubules were noted (Hazard Assessment Report (CERI, NITE) 2004). Since these effects were seen at doses that fall under Category 1 guidance values, the substance was classified into Category 1 for the digestive system, respiratory system, kidney, and liver.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.classification:
Category 1 (kidney),
Category 2 (liver, digestive system),
Category 3 (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement:
Causes damage to organs (kidney)
May cause damage to organs (liver, digestive system)
May cause respiratory irritation (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Although there are no test results available for this substance, oral administration of epichlorohydrin (CAS No. 106-89-8) in animal tests resulted in kidney failure, fatty metamorphosis in the liver, necrosis of gastrointestinal tract, and respiratory tract irritation (Hazard Assessment Report (CERI, NITE) 2004). The effect of administration on the kidney was seen at doses that fall under Category 1 guidance values and that on the liver and gastrointestinal tract was noted at doses that fall under Category 2 guidance values. Based on the results above, the substance was classified into Category 1 for the kidney, Category 2 for the liver and digestive system, and Category 3 for respiratory tract irritation.
